awd_titl_txt: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Architecting Performance Sensitive Applications for the Cloud
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing offers IT organizations the ability to create
geo-distributed, and highly scalable applications while providing
attractive cost-saving advantages. Yet, architecting, configuring, and
adapting cloud applications (latency-sensitive web applications and
bulk data processing applications) to meet their stringent performance
requirements is a challenge given the rich set of configuration
options, shared multi-tenant nature of cloud platforms, and dynamics
resulting from activities such as planned maintenance.

This project is developing novel methodologies, algorithms, and
systems that can enable application architects to (1) judiciously
architect applications across multiple cloud data-centers while
considering application performance requirements, cost saving
objectives, and cloud pricing schemes guided by performance and cost
models of cloud components; (2) automatically learn effective
application configurations and configuration-to-performance prediction
models through statistical machine learning techniques; and (3) create
applications that can adapt to ongoing dynamics in cloud environments
through transaction reassignment over shorter time-scales, and
application migration over longer time-scales.

The impact of this research is multi-fold: (1) Enable IT organizations
to significantly reduce costs by optimally moving their operations to
the cloud; (2) create benchmarks based on operationally deployed
applications and collecting workload traces which will be made
available to the research community; (3) make developed algorithms and
systems widely available as open source software; (4) inform the
design of a nation-wide health-care cloud in Thailand; (4) introduce
cloud computing related topics in the undergraduate and graduate
curriculum; and (6) train multiple Ph.D., M.S., and undergraduate
students, with explicit effort to recruit and train students from
under-represented minority groups.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project have drastically improved the flexibility of the cloud infrastructure and the performance of applications in the cloud. We have developed a live virtual machine migration progress management system called Pacer that enables migration time prediction, application interference minimization, and migration deadline selection and enforcement. We have developed a multi-tier application migration system called COMMA, and develop a new communication-cost-driven coordinated approach for virtual machine migration to minimize disruption to multi-tier applications during migration. We have developed new methodologies for application-specific configuration selection in the cloud through a detailed study of Amazon EC2's performance variations and policies (e.g. rate limitation, virtualization, CPU scheduling, resource allocation, etc.). Based on this understanding of the impact of provider policy, we have developed algorithms for selecting cloud configurations that can best meet the cost and performance requirements of applications. We have further extended this work by collaborating with Burstorm, a CAD application vendor for cloud architects, and benchmarked the performance of seven cloud service suppliers (including Amazon, Google, Microsoft, Rackspace, HP, Linode, and Softlayer) across three continents with a total of 96 different instance types. Using these results, cloud application developers can optimally choose the cloud service for their price-performance requirements. We have developed topological flexibility through reconfigurable network hardware called OmniSwitch as a method for adapting multi-tenant cloud network to tenant workload by provisioning bandwidth for cloud tenants and reducing transmission hop count at low computation cost. We have developed a new cloud file system called Pfimbi that supports flow-controlled asynchronous data replication to accelerate jobs, exploit under-utilized storage I/O bandwidth, and support hierarchical storage I/O bandwidth allocation policies. We have conducted a detailed diagnosis of the memory pressure problem in cloud data processing frameworks and identified reasons for their performance collapse, and we have proposed a novel programming abstraction called the leaky buffer that eliminates the underlying problem, thereby greatly improving the performance of these cloud data processing frameworks.

This project has provided many exciting opportunities for graduate student training in cutting edge networking technologies. The project has also supported students from under-represented minority groups. Specifically, this project has provided training opportunities to two female graduate students. Five graduate students partially supported by this project have received the M.S. degree.
